awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A History of Muscle-Powered Transportation Infrastructure Planning and the Broader Political Economy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a doctoral dissertation research project in the history of technology that focuses on muscle-powered transportation and the political economy of transportation technology infrastructure. The project involves archival research and oral history interviews. The historical data promises to illuminate socio-technological policies and practices. The results of this study will be of interest to colleagues working on various disciplines including Science and Technology Studies and Infrastructure Studies through workshops and academic conferences, and they will be incorporated into university courses and presented to broader audiences through public lectures. 

The doctoral dissertation researcher will spend five months conducting research in three counties interviewing locals and consulting archives. The research will triangulate the textual, visual and ethnographical data collected to bring to light insights concerning transportation infrastructure planning and the broader political economy of transportation technology. The project will use the theoretical insights by incorporating actor-network theory into the socio-political context in order to engage with a scholarly tradition that critically reflects on the politics of technology, which holds that the politics of technology embedded in man-machine relations is not universal across time and space, but must be examined in its political, social, and environmental system. By employing a framework of actor-network theory in this way, the project will investigate the multi-layered, multi-directional relations that transportation technologies foster between users and other actors in the socio-politico-technological system. In so doing, it expands the theoretical framework of ANT by reconceptualizing the actors and the network in a broader context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Today, China and Technology are linked in the public imagination to an extent that is unprecedented. However, the assumption that China's rise is a purely post-socialist phenomenon obscures the socialist origins of China's technological systems. My project intervenes in this public interest bias by collecting, analyzing, and sharing the historical data that illuminate the socialist legacy existing in contemporary China's socio-technological policies and practices. I have shared my research with colleagues working on various disciplines including STS Studies and East Asia Studies through workshops and academic conferences. In August 2021, I presented my research on the labor organization and technology during the Great Leap Forward at the 2021 Mini-Conference of the Twentieth-Century China. I also shared my research on how the Chinese Communist Party established a new labor regime through an examination on the standardization of earthwork practice in the early 1950s at the Trans-East Asia Workshop at the University of Chicago. My research will be presented at 2022 Association for Asian Studies Conference in a panel that focuses on the change in engineering practices from the Republican era to the PRC.  

            Employing my research findings, I designed a course "Infrastructure: Past, Present, and Future" for the Global Studies Program at the University of Chicago. The proposal is currently under review. If approved, I will teach this course to undergrad students at the university in Spring 2022. This course surveys the social, cultural and economic impact of infrastructure through historical and anthropological lenses. It examines both theoretical foundations and empirical cases of infrastructure and technology as the issue comes to occupy the central stage of political debate in the US and worldwide. I will bring my research on infrastructure building in Socialist China into a broad array of topics, including but not limited to: the age-long argument on hydraulic civilization, the co-construction of infrastructure and nation-state, as well as infrastructure and internationalism.

            The support from the National Science Foundation was critical to the successful completion of this research. I will continue to share my work through my future writing and teaching.
